messageBody:
There are always extremes. Anything can be overdone, and therefore result in loss of benefit. The trick is optimizing your outcome.

I don't think that most people who are truly practicing TDD (following the intent, if not the letter) could be "obsessed over tests to the exclusion of customer satisfaction".

I look at TDD as being driven largely by customer need. If I don't understand the customer need (and therefore how to satisfy them), then I don't know what to test for. If I don't know what to test for, I don't know what to write. Therefore, if my tests are based on meeting customer need (which drives customer satisfaction), then I inherently should improve customer satisfaction with every test I write, because it will result in code that meets their needs.

Being focused on the customer, though, I will also realize that writing umpteen-million tests for one piece of functionality, to the detriment of not creating other necessary functionality, would not enhance customer satisfaction. :)

It's a balancing act, but well worth the effort.


my two cents,
Dianne

> because TDD is /a method for thinking carefully about a design/!

the tests at the exclusion of all other factors (such as, I don't know,
customer satisfaction :-)).
